elements.content: A total of six three-dimensional chiral coordination compounds l- and d-[LnZn­(IN)3­(C2H4O2)] n (Ln = Eu, Sm, and Gd; HIN = isonicotinic acid) have been successfully synthesized under hydrothermal conditions without any chiral auxiliary and characterized by IR, TG, elemental analyses, and solid-state circular dichroism spectra. The structures of 1–6 were determined by single-crystal X-ray structural analysis, which shows that l-[LnZn­(IN)3­(C2H4O2)] n (Ln = Eu (1), Sm (2), and Gd (3)) crystallize in space group P6522 and are levogyrate. The chiral frameworks of l-[LnZn­(IN)3(C2H4O2)] n are constructed from l-helical Ln-O-Zn cluster chains, while adjacent l-type helical −[Ln-O-Zn] n – chains are connected through IN– ligands. d-[LnZn­(IN)3­(C2H4O2)] n (Ln = Eu (4), Sm (5), and Gd (6)) crystallize in space group P6122, and their chiral frameworks consist of d-helical Ln-O-Zn cluster chains. The observed second-harmonic generation efficiencies of [EuZn­(IN)3­(C2H4O2)] n , [SmZn­(IN)3­(C2H4O2)] n , and [GdZn­(IN)3­(C2H4O2)] n are 0.4, 0.3, and 0.3 times that of urea, respectively. We also studied luminescence spectra and luminescence lifetimes of 1 and 2. The luminescence lifetimes of 1 and 2 are 1.18 ms, and 29.6 μs, respectively.

The chiral frameworks of l-[LnZn(IN)3(C2H4O2)] n  are constructed from l-helical Ln-O-Zn cluster chains, while adjacent l-type helical -[Ln-O-Zn] n - chains are connected through IN- ligands. d-[LnZn(IN)3(C2H4O2)] n  (Ln = Eu (4), Sm (5), and Gd (6)) crystallize in space group P6122, and their chiral frameworks consist of d-helical Ln-O-Zn cluster chains. The observed second-harmonic generation efficiencies of [EuZn(IN)3(C2H4O2)] n , [SmZn(IN)3(C2H4O2)] n , and [GdZn(IN)3(C2H4O2)] n  are 0.4, 0.3, and 0.3 times that of urea, respectively. We also studied luminescence spectra and luminescence lifetimes of 1 and 2. The luminescence lifetimes of 1 and 2 are 1.18 ms, and 29.6 μs, respectively.

elements.content: A total of six three-dimensional chiral coordination compounds l- and d-[LnZn­(IN)3­(C2H4O2)] n (Ln = Eu, Sm, and Gd; HIN = isonicotinic acid) which were all constructed by helical −[Ln-O-Zn] n − chains have been successfully synthesized under hydrothermal conditions without any chiral auxiliary. The luminescence lifetimes of [EuZn­(IN)3­(C2H4O2)] n and [SmZn­(IN)3­(C2H4O2)] n are 1.18 ms, and 29.6 μs, respectively.

elements.content: Over the past decade, the rational design and construction of 3d–4f heterometallic frameworks have been viewed with great interest, not only because of their impressive structural diversity in terms of architecture and topology, but also due to their potential application in the fields of magnetism, chemical sensors, adsorption, catalysis, biomedical research, and luminescence. Many 3d–4f heterometallic complexes have been reported, and most of the research attention is placed on the magnetic complexes, while the luminescent 3d–4f heterometallic complexes have received much less attention. Furthermore, lanthanide-based clusters are well-known candidates for displaying enhanced photoluminescent properties attributing to f–f transitions. This is especially true for Eu­(III) compounds. The transition-metal ions, such as Zn­(II), exhibit peculiar chemical and physical properties in virtue of diverse 3d electrons. Thus, the combination of lanthanide-based cluster and transition-metal ions into one coordination polymer could provide an avenue for the construction of novel luminescent materials. Considering the development of the luminescent monometallic complexes containing lanthanide ions or d10 transition-metal ions, we could anticipate the importance of the heterometallic complexes with both lanthanide and d10 metal ions on the luminescence materials.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Over the past decade, the rational design and construction of 3d-4f heterometallic frameworks have been viewed with great interest, not only because of their impressive structural diversity in terms of architecture and topology, but also due to their potential application in the fields of magnetism, chemical sensors, adsorption, catalysis, biomedical research, and luminescence. Many 3d-4f heterometallic complexes have been reported, and most of the research attention is placed on the magnetic complexes, while the luminescent 3d-4f heterometallic complexes have received much less attention. Furthermore, lanthanide-based clusters are well-known candidates for displaying enhanced photoluminescent properties attributing to f-f transitions. This is especially true for Eu(III) compounds. The transition-metal ions, such as Zn(II), exhibit peculiar chemical and physical properties in virtue of diverse 3d electrons. Thus, the combination of lanthanide-based cluster and transition-metal ions into one coordination polymer could provide an avenue for the construction of novel luminescent materials. Considering the development of the luminescent monometallic complexes containing lanthanide ions or d10 transition-metal ions, we could anticipate the importance of the heterometallic complexes with both lanthanide and d10 metal ions on the luminescence materials.

elements.content: On the other hand, considerable research effort has been devoted to the design and syntheses of novel 3d–4f heterometallic complexes. However, the syntheses is still a challenge for the coordination characteristics of the metal ions to the organic ligands. The high coordination numbers and flexible coordination geometries of lanthanide ions make it difficult to control the preparation of the 3d–4f heterometallic complexes. Therefore, the selection of suitable organic ligands is crucial. According to the hard–soft acid–base principle, the lanthanide ions are hard acids and prefer oxygen to nitrogen donors, while the d-block transition-metal ions are borderline acids and have a strong tendency to coordinate to N donors and O donors. As a result, multidentate ligands containing N- and O-donor atoms are the best candidates in the construction of novel 3d–4f heterometallic complexes. For example, nicotinic acid, isonicotinic acid, and pyridine dicarboxylic acid have been employed extensively. Moreover, ancillary ligands with excellent chelating ability, such as acetic acid, have been widely used to prevent the coordination of solvent or water molecules with lanthanide centers.

elements.content: In the past few years, one of the important advances in coordination chemistry has been the study of the chiral coordination polymers. The synthetic methods usually have two kinds. The first way is to employ chiral organic ligands in stereoselective synthesis, while the second way is spontaneous resolution upon crystallization without chiral species. By the first approach, many chiral coordination polymers have been obtained. In contrast, chiral coordination polymers generated by the second method are still rare because their mechanism remains poorly understood. There are only a few examples of spontaneous resolution, where the chiral information in the building units can be transmitted into higher dimensionality to generate chiral coordination polymers. Almost all of these reported chiral coordination polymers have been attributed to a homometallic system, while the chemistry toward chiral d–f heterometallic coordination polymers based on spontaneous resolution remains largely unexplored.

By the first approach, many chiral coordination polymers have been obtained. In contrast, chiral coordination polymers generated by the second method are still rare because their mechanism remains poorly understood. There are only a few examples of spontaneous resolution, where the chiral information in the building units can be transmitted into higher dimensionality to generate chiral coordination polymers. Almost all of these reported chiral coordination polymers have been attributed to a homometallic system, while the chemistry toward chiral d-f heterometallic coordination polymers based on spontaneous resolution remains largely unexplored.

elements.content: Herein, we report the hydrothermal syntheses and structural characterizations of six chiral 3D framework lanthanide coordination compounds: l- and d-[LnZn­(IN)3­(C2H4O2)] n (Ln = Eu, Sm, and Gd; HIN = isonicotinic acid), which are composed of the −[Ln-O-Zn] n – chiral helical chains. In the structures of the compounds, the isonicotinate (IN–) is the main ligand while ethylene glycol functions as the ancillary ligand. The six compounds were prepared under the same initial reaction conditions. Structural analysis indicates that compounds are built up of the −[Ln-O-Zn] n – chiral helical chains which are connected by IN– ligands to give a 2D layered structure. Furthermore, the adjacent 2D layered structures are connected by IN– ligands to make an interesting chiral 3D framework. If the symmetry of P6522 is chosen, the chirality of the framework should be levogyrate, while dextrogyrous chiral frameworks choose the symmetry of P6122. It is noteworthy that the helical chains with Ln-O-M connectivity are quite rare. Up to now, to our knowledge, compounds 1–6 represent the first chiral examples for 3d–4f heterometallic coordination polymers.

In the structures of the compounds, the isonicotinate (IN-) is the main ligand while ethylene glycol functions as the ancillary ligand. The six compounds were prepared under the same initial reaction conditions. Structural analysis indicates that compounds are built up of the -[Ln-O-Zn] n - chiral helical chains which are connected by IN- ligands to give a 2D layered structure. Furthermore, the adjacent 2D layered structures are connected by IN- ligands to make an interesting chiral 3D framework. If the symmetry of P6522 is chosen, the chirality of the framework should be levogyrate, while dextrogyrous chiral frameworks choose the symmetry of P6122. It is noteworthy that the helical chains with Ln-O-M connectivity are quite rare. Up to now, to our knowledge, compounds 1-6 represent the first chiral examples for 3d-4f heterometallic coordination polymers.

elements.content: All chemicals purchased were of reagent grade and were used without further purification. IR spectra were recorded on a Nicolet Impact 410 Fourier transform infrared spectrometer using KBr pellets in the 4000–500 cm–1 region. The C, H, and N elemental analyses were performed on a Perkin–Elmer 2400 elemental analyzer. TG measurement was carried out on a Diamond thermogravimetric analyzer in a flowing N2 atmosphere from 25 to 1000 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C min–1. The solid-state emission/excitation spectra were measured on an FP-6500 spectrofluorimeter equipped with a 450 W xenon lamp as the excitation source. Single-crystal structure determination was performed on a Bruker APEX2 CCD diffractometer at 296 K and a sealed tube X-ray source (Mo Kα radiation, λ = 0.71073 Å) operating at 50 kV and 30 mA. The circular dichroism (CD) spectra were recorded on a JASCOJ-810 spectropolarimeter with KBr pellets. Optical second-harmonic generation (SHG) was investigated by a Q-switched Nd:YAG laser (wavelength = 1064 nm and pulse width = 10 ns) at room temperature.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

All chemicals purchased were of reagent grade and were used without further purification. IR spectra were recorded on a Nicolet Impact 410 Fourier transform infrared spectrometer using KBr pellets in the 4000-500 cm-1 region. The C, H, and N elemental analyses were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 2400 elemental analyzer. TG measurement was carried out on a Diamond thermogravimetric analyzer in a flowing N2 atmosphere from 25 to 1000 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C min-1. The solid-state emission/excitation spectra were measured on an FP-6500 spectrofluorimeter equipped with a 450 W xenon lamp as the excitation source. Single-crystal structure determination was performed on a Bruker APEX2 CCD diffractometer at 296 K and a sealed tube X-ray source (Mo Kα radiation, λ = 0.71073 Å) operating at 50 kV and 30 mA. The circular dichroism (CD) spectra were recorded on a JASCOJ-810 spectropolarimeter with KBr pellets. Optical second-harmonic generation (SHG) was investigated by a Q-switched Nd:YAG laser (wavelength = 1064 nm and pulse width = 10 ns) at room temperature.

elements.content: A mixture of Eu2O3 (0.30 mmol, 0.1056 g), HIN (0.90 mmol, 0.1108 g), Zn­(Ac)2·2H2O (0.30 mmol, 0.0650 g), deionized water (2 mL), and ethylene glycol (4 mL) was stirred for 60 min. The mixture was sealed in a 24 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and heated at 180 °C for 6 days. After being cooled to room temperature, and washed with anhydrous ethanol, colorless block crystals were obtained. Yield: 0.12 g, 64% (based on Zn, 1: 49%, 4: 51%; 1 and 4 were separated by polarizing microscope). Anal. Calcd for C20H16N3O8EuZn: C, 37.30; H, 2.49; N, 6.53. Elemental analysis: found C, 37.18; H, 2.40; N, 6.48. IR (KBr pellet, cm–1): 3488 (s), 1632 (s), 1606 (s), 1385 (s), 1102 (w), 774 (w), 708 (w), 687 (m).

elements.content: The single crystals of compounds were singled out by visual examination under the microscope and glued at the top of a thin glass fiber with epoxy glue in air for data collection. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction data were collected on a Bruker APEX2 CCD diffractometer with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 296 K via the ω-2θ scan method. A total of six structures were solved by direct methods and refined on F 2 by full-matrix least-squares methods using the SHELX-2014/7 crystallographic software package. All non-H atoms were refined anisotropically. The H atoms of the organic amine templates were included in calculated positions, assigned isotropic displacement parameters, and allowed to ride on their parent atoms. A summary of the crystallographic data and structural determination for compounds is provided in .

X-ray Crystallography

The single crystals of compounds were singled out by visual examination under the microscope and glued at the top of a thin glass fiber with epoxy glue in air for data collection. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction data were collected on a Bruker APEX2 CCD diffractometer with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 296 K via the ω-2θ scan method. A total of six structures were solved by direct methods and refined on F 2 by full-matrix least-squares methods using the SHELX-2014/7 crystallographic software package. All non-H atoms were refined anisotropically. The H atoms of the organic amine templates were included in calculated positions, assigned isotropic displacement parameters, and allowed to ride on their parent atoms. A summary of the crystallographic data and structural determination for compounds is provided in .

Hydrothermal synthesis has recently been demonstrated to be a powerful method in the synthesis of solid-state rare-earth clusters. During a specific hydrothermal synthesis, many factors can affect the nucleation and crystal growth of the final products, such as the type of initial reactants, starting concentrations of the reactants, pH values, solvents, reaction temperature, and reaction time. In our case, solvent (ethylene glycol) plays an important role in the formation of compounds 1–6. It acts not only as the solvent but also as a ligand, which can compensate the charge and establish a stable structure. Meanwhile, the temperature has great influence on the yields of 1–6. We tried to change the reaction temperature to 80–180 °C, and the yields are the highest when the reaction temperature is 180 °C. In addition, during the formation of the title six chiral compounds, Ln2O3 is excessive. The parallel experiment indicates that, if the proportion of Ln2O3 in initial reactants was reduced, the yield of products will be decreased. Furthermore, we have tried to replace ethylene glycol by ethanediamine and hope to obtain chiral compounds, but the comparative experiments indicate that only block-like crystals of [Ln­(NC6H4O2)3­(H2O)2] n were formed (unit cell: a = 20.2688 Å, b = 11.6055 Å, c = 9.8653 Å, α = 90°, β = 115.626°, γ = 90°). Compounds 1–6 could be easily obtained under solvothermal synthesis and have good reproducibility.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis

Hydrothermal synthesis has recently been demonstrated to be a powerful method in the synthesis of solid-state rare-earth clusters. During a specific hydrothermal synthesis, many factors can affect the nucleation and crystal growth of the final products, such as the type of initial reactants, starting concentrations of the reactants, pH values, solvents, reaction temperature, and reaction time. In our case, solvent (ethylene glycol) plays an important role in the formation of compounds 1-6. It acts not only as the solvent but also as a ligand, which can compensate the charge and establish a stable structure. Meanwhile, the temperature has great influence on the yields of 1-6. We tried to change the reaction temperature to 80-180 °C, and the yields are the highest when the reaction temperature is 180 °C. In addition, during the formation of the title six chiral compounds, Ln2O3 is excessive. The parallel experiment indicates that, if the proportion of Ln2O3 in initial reactants was reduced, the yield of products will be decreased. Furthermore, we have tried to replace ethylene glycol by ethanediamine and hope to obtain chiral compounds, but the comparative experiments indicate that only block-like crystals of [Ln(NC6H4O2)3(H2O)2] n  were formed (unit cell: a = 20.2688 Å, b = 11.6055 Å, c = 9.8653 Å, α = 90°, β = 115.626°, γ = 90°). Compounds 1-6 could be easily obtained under solvothermal synthesis and have good reproducibility.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses revealed that compounds 1–3 are isostructural and their crystal system, space group, unit cell dimensions, related bond distances, and bond angles are only slightly different. Therefore, only the structure of 1 will be discussed in detail. Compound 1 crystallizes in the chiral hexagonal space group P6522. A perspective view of the molecular structure of 1 is displayed in a. The structure unit of 1 contains one crystallographically independent Eu3+ ion, one Zn2+ ion, three IN– ligands, and one C2H4O2 2– ligand (a). As shown in a, the Eu­(III) center is eight-coordinated and employs a distorted square antiprism coordination geometry (Supporting Information, Figure S16) to generate a perfect “butterfly” accomplished by six carboxylate oxygen atoms from six different IN– ligands, and the other two oxygen atoms from one deprotonated ethylene glycol ligand C2H4O2 2–. The Eu–O distances are from 2.390(5) to 2.462(4) Å and the O–Eu–O bond angles range from 67.9(2)° to 157.6(2)°. The values fall into the reported normal range. The Zn atom is coordinated to two carboxyl oxygen atoms and two nitrogen atoms from two different IN– ligands in a distorted tetrahedron (Supporting Information, Figure S17), where the most distorted angle is O(4)–Zn(1)–N(1) at 98.5(2)°. The Zn–O and Zn–N bond lengths are 1.897(4) and 2.147(6) Å, respectively, which are similar to those found in the related Zn­(II) complexes.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structures of l-[LnZn(IN)3(C2H4O2)] n  (1-3)

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses revealed that compounds 1-3 are isostructural and their crystal system, space group, unit cell dimensions, related bond distances, and bond angles are only slightly different. Therefore, only the structure of 1 will be discussed in detail. Compound 1 crystallizes in the chiral hexagonal space group P6522. A perspective view of the molecular structure of 1 is displayed in a. The structure unit of 1 contains one crystallographically independent Eu3+ ion, one Zn2+ ion, three IN- ligands, and one C2H4O2 2- ligand (a). As shown in a, the Eu(III) center is eight-coordinated and employs a distorted square antiprism coordination geometry (Supporting Information, Figure S16) to generate a perfect "butterfly" accomplished by six carboxylate oxygen atoms from six different IN- ligands, and the other two oxygen atoms from one deprotonated ethylene glycol ligand C2H4O2 2-. The Eu-O distances are from 2.390(5) to 2.462(4) Å and the O-Eu-O bond angles range from 67.9(2)° to 157.6(2)°. The values fall into the reported normal range. The Zn atom is coordinated to two carboxyl oxygen atoms and two nitrogen atoms from two different IN- ligands in a distorted tetrahedron (Supporting Information, Figure S17), where the most distorted angle is O(4)-Zn(1)-N(1) at 98.5(2)°. The Zn-O and Zn-N bond lengths are 1.897(4) and 2.147(6) Å, respectively, which are similar to those found in the related Zn(II) complexes.

elements.content: As shown in , the IN– ligands exhibit two kinds of coordination modes: (a) For coordination mode I, each of the oxygen atoms of the carboxyl coordinates to a Eu atom by a bridging bidentate coordination mode, while the nitrogen atom coordinates to a Zn atom. (b) For coordination mode II, each of the oxygen atoms of the carboxyl coordinates to a Eu atom by a bridging bidentate coordination mode. The C2H4O2 2– ligand displays one kind of coordination mode: each of the oxygen atoms coordinates to a Zn atom. Simultaneously, the two oxygen atoms coordinate to a Eu atom by the chelating bidentate mode (c).

elements.content: In the structure of 1, the chiral unit can be considered as a left-handed inorganic heterometallic helical chain built up from the alternate Eu and Zn coordination centers with shared O atoms (a). Adjacent helical chains are further connected by IN– ligands with the coordination mode I to 2D layer (b). Similarly, the adjacent 2D layered structures are connected by IN– ligands with the coordination mode I exhibiting a 3D framework (c).

elements.content: Viewing along the c axis, it is noticeable that every left-handed helical chain forms a snowflake type, which is surrounded by six snowflake chains with the same handedness (). The most fascinating structural feature of compound 1 is the transition of chirality from the left-handed −[Eu-O-Zn] n – heterometallic helical chains to the three-dimensional heterometallic coordination polymers through the coordination bonds between IN– ligands and two types of metal centers. The Flack parameter of −0.016(15) for compound 1 indicates that the absolute configurations are correct.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses revealed that compounds 4–6 are isostructural and their crystal system, space group, unit-cell dimensions, related bond distances, and bond angles are only slightly different. Therefore, only the structure of 4 will be discussed in detail. Compound 4 crystallizes in the chiral hexagonal space group P6122. In the structure of 4, adjacent Eu atoms and Zn atoms are connected through O atoms to form the right-handed helical chain. Adjacent helical chains are further connected by IN– ligands with the coordination mode I to 2D layer. Similarly, the adjacent 2D layered structures are connected by IN– ligands with the coordination mode I exhibiting a 3D framework.Viewing along the c axis, it is remarkable that every right-handed helical chain forms a snowflake type, which is surrounded by six snowflake chains with the same handedness (Supporting Information, Figure S18). The fascinating structural feature of compound 4 is the transition of chirality from the left-handed −[Eu-O-Zn] n – heterometallic helical chains to the three-dimensional heterometallic coordination polymers through the coordination bonds between IN– ligands and two types of metal centers. The Flack parameter of 0.02(3) for compound 4 indicates that the absolute configurations are correct.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structures of d-[LnZn(IN)3(C2H4O2)] n  (4-6)

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses revealed that compounds 4-6 are isostructural and their crystal system, space group, unit-cell dimensions, related bond distances, and bond angles are only slightly different. Therefore, only the structure of 4 will be discussed in detail. Compound 4 crystallizes in the chiral hexagonal space group P6122. In the structure of 4, adjacent Eu atoms and Zn atoms are connected through O atoms to form the right-handed helical chain. Adjacent helical chains are further connected by IN- ligands with the coordination mode I to 2D layer. Similarly, the adjacent 2D layered structures are connected by IN- ligands with the coordination mode I exhibiting a 3D framework.Viewing along the c axis, it is remarkable that every right-handed helical chain forms a snowflake type, which is surrounded by six snowflake chains with the same handedness (Supporting Information, Figure S18). The fascinating structural feature of compound 4 is the transition of chirality from the left-handed -[Eu-O-Zn] n - heterometallic helical chains to the three-dimensional heterometallic coordination polymers through the coordination bonds between IN- ligands and two types of metal centers. The Flack parameter of 0.02(3) for compound 4 indicates that the absolute configurations are correct.

elements.content: Homochiral d–f coordination polymers generated by the spontaneous resolution are very rare, and the chiral enantiomers based on spontaneous resolution are much less. Xue ’ s group has reported two similar chiral Ln-O-Ag coordination polymers, which were obtained from the aqueous solution of Nd2O3/Eu2O3, AgNO3, HIN, and HOAc at 180 °C. OAc ligands connect to two types of metal centers in both chelating and bridging modes along different directions, which, therefore, lead to a noncentrosymmetric organization and a twist of the chain and the helical structure finally forms. Both polymers are constructed from infinite right-handed homochiral helical chains. They have pointed out that the factors governing the formation of the compounds are the inducement of the Ag­(I) ion and the coordination mode of OAc. Different from Xue, we adopt Zn­(II) as transition metal and ethylene glycol/deionized water as solvent and find that the coordination mode of ethylene glycol may be the key factor controlling the formation of three chiral enantiomers, which were examined by using solid-state CD spectroscopy.

elements.content: The measured and simulated powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns of 1–6 are shown in Figures S7–S12 (Supporting Information). The measured XRD patterns are in agreement with the calculated patterns, which indicate the phase purity of compounds 1–6. The differences in reflection intensities during collection of the experimental XRD data are probably due to the preferred orientation effect of the powder.
elements.clean_text:
Powder X-ray Diffraction

The measured and simulated powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns of 1-6 are shown in Figures S7-S12 (Supporting Information). The measured XRD patterns are in agreement with the calculated patterns, which indicate the phase purity of compounds 1-6. The differences in reflection intensities during collection of the experimental XRD data are probably due to the preferred orientation effect of the powder.

elements.content: The homochirality of complex 1 was further confirmed by solid-state circular dichroism (CD) spectra, which were obtained from KBr pellets using a single crystal (). The first Cotton effect is negative, and the second is positive, proving that coordination polymer 1 is l-chiral, whereas compound 4 shows opposite Cotton effects at the same wavelengths. This signifies that they are enantiomers.

elements.content: Since 1 and 4 are enantiomers, we study the luminescence properties of 1. The dynamics of the Eu3+ PL was measured at room temperature ( ). The luminescence decay was successfully fitted by ways of a single exponential law (square correlation factor R 2 > 0.99). From the decay curve of 5D0 → 7F2 from Eu3+ in 1 under 395 nm excitation, the decay lifetime was determined to be 1.18 ms, which is significantly higher than the values obtained for reported Eu3+ coordination polymers in the solid state at room temperature. As shown in , under 395 nm excitation wavelength, the solid emission spectrum of compound 1 demonstrates a characteristic transition of Eu3+: 5D0 → 7F0 (579 nm), 5D0 → 7F1 (590 nm), 5D0 → 7F2 (612 nm), 5D0 → 7F3 (650 nm), and 5D0 → 7F4 (702 nm). The existence of the 5D0 → 7F0 (579 nm) symmetry-forbidden transition emission spectrum illustrates that Eu3+ is in the presence of a noncentrosymmetric coordination environment. As we know, the magnetic dipole transition 5D0 → 7F1 is insensitive and hardly varies with the coordination environment, whereas the electric dipole transition 5D0 → 7F2 is a hypersensitive transition, whose intensity is very sensitive and apt to be influenced by the host environment. From the figure, we can clearly see that 5D0 → 7F2 (the electric dipole transition emission peak) is significantly stronger than the 5D0 → 7F1, which also indicates that Eu3+ has the lower symmetric coordination environment.
elements.clean_text:
Luminescence Property

Since 1 and 4 are enantiomers, we study the luminescence properties of 1. The dynamics of the Eu3+ PL was measured at room temperature ( ). The luminescence decay was successfully fitted by ways of a single exponential law (square correlation factor R 2 > 0.99). From the decay curve of 5D0 → 7F2 from Eu3+ in 1 under 395 nm excitation, the decay lifetime was determined to be 1.18 ms, which is significantly higher than the values obtained for reported Eu3+ coordination polymers in the solid state at room temperature. As shown in , under 395 nm excitation wavelength, the solid emission spectrum of compound 1 demonstrates a characteristic transition of Eu3+: 5D0 → 7F0 (579 nm), 5D0 → 7F1 (590 nm), 5D0 → 7F2 (612 nm), 5D0 → 7F3 (650 nm), and 5D0 → 7F4 (702 nm). The existence of the 5D0 → 7F0 (579 nm) symmetry-forbidden transition emission spectrum illustrates that Eu3+ is in the presence of a noncentrosymmetric coordination environment. As we know, the magnetic dipole transition 5D0 → 7F1 is insensitive and hardly varies with the coordination environment, whereas the electric dipole transition 5D0 → 7F2 is a hypersensitive transition, whose intensity is very sensitive and apt to be influenced by the host environment. From the figure, we can clearly see that 5D0 → 7F2 (the electric dipole transition emission peak) is significantly stronger than the 5D0 → 7F1, which also indicates that Eu3+ has the lower symmetric coordination environment.

elements.content: For 2 and 5, we studied the luminescence properties of 2. The dynamics of the Sm3+ PL was measured at room temperature (Supporting Information, Figure S21). The luminescence decay was successfully fitted by ways of a single exponential law (square correlation factor R 2 > 0.99). From the decay curve of 4G5/2 → 6H9/2 from Sm3+ in 2 under 400 nm excitation, the decay lifetime was determined to be 29.6 μs. As shown in , complex 2 displays the characteristic emissions of the Sm­(III) ion at 554, 598, 645, and 694 nm, which correspond to the 4G5/2 → 6H J (J = 5/2, 7/2, 9/2, 11/2) transitions. Among them, the most intense emission at 645 nm belongs to the hypersensitive 4G5/2 → 6H9/2 transition. The emission peak at 498 nm among the emission bands in a range of 400–500 nm from the ligand also appears in the emission spectrum of 2, which indicates that the energy transfer from the ligand to the metal center is not complete.

elements.content: Second-order nonlinear optical effect for the powder samples of mixed l- and d-[EuZn­(IN)3­(C2H4O2)] n , [SmZn­(IN)3­(C2H4O2)] n , and [GdZn­(IN)3­(C2H4O2)] n were investigated by optical second-harmonic generation (SHG) at room temperature. SHG intensity data were obtained by placing the powder sample in an intense fundamental beam from a Q-switched Nd:YAG laser with a wavelength 1064 nm. The output (λ = 532 nm) was filtered first to remove the multiplier and then displayed on an oscilloscope. This procedure was repeated using a standard NLO material (microcrystalline urea), and the ratio of the second-harmonic intensity outputs was calculated. The SHG efficiencies of 0.4, 0.3, and 0.3 times that of urea for [EuZn­(IN)3­(C2H4O2)] n , [SmZn­(IN)3­(C2H4O2)] n , and [GdZn­(IN)3­(C2H4O2)] n , respectively, were observed.
elements.clean_text:
Nonlinear Optical Measurement

Second-order nonlinear optical effect for the powder samples of mixed l- and d-[EuZn(IN)3(C2H4O2)] n , [SmZn(IN)3(C2H4O2)] n , and [GdZn(IN)3(C2H4O2)] n  were investigated by optical second-harmonic generation (SHG) at room temperature. SHG intensity data were obtained by placing the powder sample in an intense fundamental beam from a Q-switched Nd:YAG laser with a wavelength 1064 nm. The output (λ = 532 nm) was filtered first to remove the multiplier and then displayed on an oscilloscope. This procedure was repeated using a standard NLO material (microcrystalline urea), and the ratio of the second-harmonic intensity outputs was calculated. The SHG efficiencies of 0.4, 0.3, and 0.3 times that of urea for [EuZn(IN)3(C2H4O2)] n , [SmZn(IN)3(C2H4O2)] n , and [GdZn(IN)3(C2H4O2)] n , respectively, were observed.

elements.content: In summary, six novel chiral Ln–Zn coordination compounds have been synthesized. Those complexes are rare examples of 3D d–f chiral heterometal coordination compounds by using an achiral ligand. The formations of six chiral compounds show an intriguing example of completed resolution in chirality, a progression from achiral species to chiral helical chains, and finally to chiral crystals. Our results not only provide an intriguing example of preparing coordination polymers with multitype metal ions and ligands but also promise a new strategy for constructing chiral coordination compounds by using an achiral ligand. Of particular interest, [EuZn­(IN)3­(C2H4O2)] n and [SmZn­(IN)3­(C2H4O2)] n show good luminescence properties. Further systematic studies for the design and synthesis of such crystalline materials based on the HIN ligand with other auxiliary ligands are currently under way.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, six novel chiral Ln-Zn coordination compounds have been synthesized. Those complexes are rare examples of 3D d-f chiral heterometal coordination compounds by using an achiral ligand. The formations of six chiral compounds show an intriguing example of completed resolution in chirality, a progression from achiral species to chiral helical chains, and finally to chiral crystals. Our results not only provide an intriguing example of preparing coordination polymers with multitype metal ions and ligands but also promise a new strategy for constructing chiral coordination compounds by using an achiral ligand. Of particular interest, [EuZn(IN)3(C2H4O2)] n  and [SmZn(IN)3(C2H4O2)] n  show good luminescence properties. Further systematic studies for the design and synthesis of such crystalline materials based on the HIN ligand with other auxiliary ligands are currently under way.

A mixture of Eu2O3 (0.30 mmol, 0.1056 g), HIN (0.90 mmol, 0.1108 g), Zn­(Ac)2·2H2O (0.30 mmol, 0.0650 g), deionized water (2 mL), and ethylene glycol (4 mL) was stirred for 60 min. The mixture was sealed in a 24 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and heated at 180 °C for 6 days. After being cooled to room temperature, and washed with anhydrous ethanol, colorless block crystals were obtained. Yield: 0.12 g, 64% (based on Zn, 1: 49%, 4: 51%; 1 and 4 were separated by polarizing microscope). Anal. Calcd for C20H16N3O8EuZn: C, 37.30; H, 2.49; N, 6.53. Elemental analysis: found C, 37.18; H, 2.40; N, 6.48. IR (KBr pellet, cm–1): 3488 (s), 1632 (s), 1606 (s), 1385 (s), 1102 (w), 774 (w), 708 (w), 687 (m).

Preparation of <sc>l</sc>- and <sc>d</sc>-SmZn­(IN)<sub>3</sub>(C<sub>2</sub>H<sub>4</sub>O<sub>2</sub>) (<bold>2</bold> and <bold>5</bold>)

A mixture of Sm2O3 (0.30 mmol, 0.1046 g), HIN (0.90 mmol, 0.1108 g), ZnSO4·7H2O (0.30 mmol, 0.0863 g), deionized water (2 mL),and ethylene glycol (4 mL) was stirred for 60 min. The mixture was sealed in a 24 mL Teflon-lined autoclave and heated at 180 °C for 6 days. After being cooled to room temperature, and washed with anhydrous ethanol, colorless block crystals were obtained. Yield: 0.13 g, 69% (based on Zn, 2: 45%, 5: 55%; 2 and 5 were separated by polarizing microscope). Anal. Calcd for C20H16­N3O8SmZn: C, 37.41; H, 2.49; N, 6.54. Elemental analysis: found C, 37.33; H, 2.88; N, 6.34. IR (KBr pellet, cm–1): 3486 (s), 1636 (s), 1603 (s), 1384 (s), 1162 (w), 773 (w), 707 (w), 625 (m).

Preparation of <sc>l</sc>- and <sc>d</sc>-GdZn­(IN)<sub>3</sub>(C<sub>2</sub>H<sub>4</sub>O<sub>2</sub>) (<bold>3</bold> and <bold>6</bold>)

Compounds 3 and 6 were synthesized in a manner similar to that described for 2 and 5, except that Sm2O3 was replaced by Gd2O3 (0.30 mmol, 0.1088 g). Colorless block crystals of 3 and 6 were obtained. Yield: 0.14 g, 73% (based on Zn, 3: 45%, 6: 55%; 3 and 6 were separated by polarizing microscope). Anal. Calcd for C20H16­N3O8GdZn: C, 36.98; H, 2.46; N, 6.47. Elemental analysis: found C, 36.53; H, 2.38; N, 6.38. IR (KBr pellet, cm–1): 3450 (s), 1640 (s), 1604 (s), 1393 (s), 1233 (w), 773 (m), 708 (m), 634 (w).

After being cooled to room temperature, and washed with anhydrous ethanol, colorless block crystals were obtained. Yield: 0.13 g, 69% (based on Zn, 2: 45%, 5: 55%; 2 and 5 were separated by polarizing microscope). Anal. Calcd for C20H16N3O8SmZn: C, 37.41; H, 2.49; N, 6.54. Elemental analysis: found C, 37.33; H, 2.88; N, 6.34. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1): 3486 (s), 1636 (s), 1603 (s), 1384 (s), 1162 (w), 773 (w), 707 (w), 625 (m).

Preparation of l- and d-GdZn(IN)3(C2H4O2) (3 and 6)

Compounds 3 and 6 were synthesized in a manner similar to that described for 2 and 5, except that Sm2O3 was replaced by Gd2O3 (0.30 mmol, 0.1088 g). Colorless block crystals of 3 and 6 were obtained. Yield: 0.14 g, 73% (based on Zn, 3: 45%, 6: 55%; 3 and 6 were separated by polarizing microscope). Anal. Calcd for C20H16N3O8GdZn: C, 36.98; H, 2.46; N, 6.47. Elemental analysis: found C, 36.53; H, 2.38; N, 6.38. IR (KBr pellet, cm-1): 3450 (s), 1640 (s), 1604 (s), 1393 (s), 1233 (w), 773 (m), 708 (m), 634 (w).
